Football practice starts Monday August 10th for both varsity (9-12 grade) and Jr. high (7-8 grade). Varsity practice will be in Turtle Lake starting at 8 in the morning. Jr. high practice will be in Underwood and the bus will be leaving at 7:30 in the morning. Jr. high should be back around 10:30.

You’re child needs to have a physical to be able to practice. If you had a physical last year there’s a form B to fill out that will cover you for this year, this can be picked up in the TL-M office if you need one. If you didn’t have a physical last year you need to get one. If you’re in Jr. high and need that form Grant Singer will have it the morning of August 10th. Be there at 7:15 so you can get them signed before your child gets on the bus. Every child should have their own water bottle to bring to practice and needs a mask to ride the bus.

There is also a parents meeting for varsity football (9-12 grade) in Underwood August 9th Sunday night at 7:30. Have at least 1 parent along with the child playing there.

2.) How long would it take if they both worked at the same rate?

4.) How long would it take each person to paint different portions of a house? For example, how long would it take them to paint 1/2 of a house?, 1/3? 2 full houses, etc. --> Can you use this to find a pattern?

ND Department of Public Instruction
March 19 at 4:00 PM ·

News from Gov. Doug Burgum and State School Superintendent Kirsten Baesler today: Public K-12 schools are ordered closed indefinitely to all except essential personnel. Schools are required to draft plans for providing distance education, and distance education instruction will count toward a school’s required minimum amount of instructional time. (Right now, distance learning does not generally count toward minimum instructional time.) Those plans must be submitted to the Department of Public Instruction by March 27. Schools will not have to make up instructional hours lost from the state’s schools being closed from March 16 until April 1. The assumption is that starting on April 1, schools will be able to provide distance instruction, in case conditions do not allow the schools themselves to reopen. Schools will receive their state education aid as normal until April 1.

ND Department of Public Instruction
March 15 at 6:48 PM ·

Governor Doug Burgum announces the closing of North Dakota’s schools, public and nonpublic, for one week, beginning Monday. The governor and State School Superintendent Kirsten Baesler explained the reasons for the shutdown Sunday night. The decision will be revisited Friday. The order does not apply to day care facilities. #COVID19

Some of the reasons for the school closings:
—The Centers for Disease Control has tightened its guidelines for large gatherings that should be avoided.
—Over the weekend, there have been reports of more North Dakotans being refused tests for COVID-19. This week-long school closing may help increase COVID-19 testing capability in North Dakota, and help to provide more information about the presence of the virus in North Dakota.
—State officials have a “more comprehensive” understanding of the ND health care system’s ability to handle a “spike” in COVID-19 cases.
